Like a million suns

This simile echoes Chapter 11, Verse 12 of the Bhagavad Gita that says “If a thousand suns were to blaze forth together in the sky, they would not match the splendor of that great form [mahātmanaḥ].”

 Chapter 11 is also known as the Vishvarupa–Darshana yoga or The Yoga of the Vision of the Cosmic Form and in it Lord Krishna shows his ‘cosmic form’ to his disciple Arjuna. Rather than a person, Krishna is revealed to be omnipresent “infinite Lord whose face is everywhere” (verse 11), One (eka-stham – in one place; verse 13), and possessed of a splendor or awesome effulgence (bhah, verse 12) that would outshine a thousand suns.

In response, Arjuna bows his head in prayerful obeisance (praṇamya, verse 14), perhaps this also finds echoes in the song’s closing phrase, “Jai Guru Deva”, is a universal Hindu blessing https://thomknoles.com/uncategorized/what-does-jai-guru-deva-mean/ e

Sounds of laughter, shades of life are ringing through my open ears
 Inciting and inviting me

This stands for the memories of good times Lennon has had in his life. The ringing could mean that it no longer is there and only acts as an echo because this was during the time the Beatles were drifting apart. Still, the lyric says that Lennon looks back fondly on his past.
They call me on and on across the universe

This line probably refers to the temptations of society and things that people cannot have and that wherever he goes, he is tempted. Either that, or it is the supposed “images of broken light”, all the things that are wrong in the world.

It is also possible that this line means that the stars, or “the universe”/“destiny” is calling for him to become one with everything. John feels he has a spiritual duty of reaching enlightenment.
Pools of sorrow, waves of joy are drifting through my opened mind

Emotions play a pivotal role in Lennon’s life – particularly at this stage. He has much to be joyful about, such as his blossoming relationship with Yoko Ono, as well as much to be sorrowful about, including the death of Brain Epstein, tensions with his band mates, and the painful memories that would lead to him taking Primal Scream Therapy.

This line also continues a pattern of comparing intangible concepts to water. Words are rain, sorrow is pools, and joy is waves.

Perhaps the pools indicate that Lennon’s sorrow was a constant lingering presence in his life, whilst the more dramatic waves of happiness hit him hard but soon passed.
Thoughts meander like a restless wind inside a letter box

Lennon, with the use of a simile, observes his reflections and ponders which, in his ‘letter box’ (mind), shall not escape.

The letterbox brings good and bad news.  While the delivery of letters can bring anxiety, an empty letterbox means that one is of no importance.
They tumble blindly as they make their way across the universe

Another play on words as Lennon continues the idea of vision through the second verse. He begins by saying that light dances like a million eyes. The word “blindly” is a play on the idea of vision he continues through verse two.  Lennon is saying that he/people search for the truth and meaning of life, (which is associated with vision and “opening your eyes” to find truth/enlightenment) throughout the entire universe. Their thoughts meander blindly, (which means they haven’t been opened yet and haven’t found the meaning of life) throughout the entire universe trying to find the truth.

Words are flowing out like endless rain into a paper cup
 They slither wildly as they slip away across the universe

Lennon wrote these lines before the rest of the words or the music. They “came to him” late at night, following an argument with Cynthia:

I was lying next to my first wife in bed, you know, and I was irritated. She must have been going on and on about something and she’d gone to sleep and I’d kept hearing these words over and over, flowing like an endless stream. I went downstairs and it turned into sort of a cosmic song rather than an irritated song…



I don’t own it, you know; it came through like that. I don’t know where it came from, what meter it’s in, and I’ve sat down and looked at it and said, ‘Can I write another one with this meter?’ It’s so interesting: ‘Words are flying [sic] out like [sings] endless rain into a paper cup, they slither while they pass, they slip away across the universe.’

–John Lennon (from All We Are Saying: The Last Major Interview with John Lennon and Yoko Ono, by David Sheff)

This story of late-night inspiration is similar to how Lennon wrote “In My Life” and “Nowhere Man.”
Images of broken light which dance before me like a million eyes

Lennon is referring to visible light in its most basic form. Without the structure and patterns provided by his logic based brain, all of life would just appear as images of broken light. After all, visible light is created by refracted photons.  But with said structure and patterns, he can view wonders like the night sky.

 Jai Guru Deva

When translating from Sanskrit: जय गुरुदेव ॐ, “Jai guru deva om”  means “I give thanks to Guru Dev (heavenly teacher) om. He’s meditating and he’s thanking god for all.

The Sanskrit phrase is a sentence fragment whose words could have many meanings. Literally it approximates as “glory to the shining remover of darkness,” and can be paraphrased as “victory to God divine”, “hail to the divine guru”, or the phrase commonly invoked by the late Maharishi Mahesh Yogi in referring to his spiritual teacher “All Glory to Guru Dev”.
